Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: obscene and non-obscene. Obscenity refers to materials and acts of pornography that are offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Damn!  Another cloudy day, and it's all Obama's doing!

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic or racism, but is not obscene.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: The suggestion that there is "human waste" spread around The Field is false. There was no poop or pee to be seen or smelled anywhere, even when we dug into huge piles of trash. The City provided Honey Bucket portable toilets, and the residents used them. 

KC Public Health is being sloppy or disingenuous here. It was filthy, yes, and there were rats, but no poop! That's important, because uncontrolled shit is so disgusting that it prejudices the discussion.

Comment: In the mid- to late 1930s France had the largest and most powerful army in the world, yet they failed to act against the fledgling German army when it violated the Versailles treaty and occupied the Rhineland. The French could have easily defeated the Germans, and removed Hitler from power, but they didn't - they sat back and watched as the Germans grew stronger, and before long, it was too late. 

Today, the US and its allies sit back and watch Kim develop nuclear-tipped ICBMs. And, they do nothing. Very, very soon, it will be too late.

Each experiment brings the North Koreans one step closer to their goal of building nuclear-tipped ICBMs that will reach North America. Once that happens,  it is a matter of when - not if - but when a nuclear missile from North Korea flattens a city in Japan, South Korea, the US or Canada. Make no mistake, it will absolutely, certainly happen. 

Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. We, evidently, have not learned a damn thing.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees.  It was the legislature, school boards, city and county governments, et al who chose to NOT pay the contribution as it was "credited" to employee retirement accounts.... This, as we're seeing today, was a MASSIVE mistake. Gary Crum

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: Fans have no desire for "brakes", nor should they, they are fans after all. Just a few months ago, fans were proclaiming  (some still are) "journeyman", "backup at best", "average ceiling - maybe", "Trevor Orton" and many more less complimentary names and insults. Through all that, a few of us were defending TS, saying "it's too early for those labels" and very few were saying "pump the brakes" then.

So, now that there's more data and the bandwagon is getting dangerously top heavy, nobody really cares (or wants) a safe ride with brakes pumped at every turn, especially when you'er 2-0 on the first 2 turns. Fans want the thrill of being 1st to cross the finish line, with every heart stopping moment and every breath taking spectacle that makes them cling to their seats and squeal for more along the way. That's football, that's entertainment and that's what fans love.

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: The people at the Denver Post ought to be smart enough to figure out this comment system makes them look both foolish and dishonest. They solicit a judgement call from their readers then sometimes penalize them for being "biased" in some unspecified way. I receive notifications of replies to comments of mine and some of these replies hardly seem to violate any reasonable standards, yet these comments sometimes mysteriously don't appear, making it look to the writer that I complained or flagged the comment in some way. On the other hand, many spiteful, untrue and rude comments do appear, making the script-driven software look amateurish and the invisible string-pullers at the Post look biased themselves. The Post can either publish or not publish my comments, it's their prerogative. The NY Times prints about 99% of my comments, no jumping through hoops required. There's a very limited amount of silly games I'm willing to play; commenting is more important to the Post than it is to me.

Comment: "Why didn’t Abraham Lincoln deport all blacks back to Africa; after all, they were definitely illegals, weren’t they?"

Actually Abraham Lincoln favored sending them back to Africa.   

"Lincoln first proclaimed an interest in colonization during his eulogy for Henry Clay in 1852, when he admitted his allegiance to the esteemed Kentuckian's dual creed of gradual emancipation coupled with colonization. If slavery could be eliminated and the slaves returned to "their long-lost fatherland," claimed Lincoln, "it will indeed be a glorious consummation."

"When Douglas tried to portray Lincoln as the friend of the blacks, Lincoln countered, as he did in a speech at Peoria, Illinois, by denying that he saw blacks as equals and by advocating the colonization of freed slaves in Liberia. Comment: I've heard this specious argument a hundred times. Seems like it never gets old for some.

"I don't hate gays, I just hate homosexuality." 
"I don't hate the Irish people, I just hate Ireland."
"I don't hate Jews, I just hate their religion."

Let's just call the argument what it is: an attempt to deny one's bigotry.

Characteristics that are intrinsic to a person's identity cannot be hated without hating the person that holds them. In Canada the core human attributes are: race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age or mental or physical disability. That's not my definition, it's explicitly stated in the Constitution of Canada.

Fundamental beliefs transcend all other human characteristics. Beliefs are intrinsic to every human being. No matter what your race, nationality, colour, sexuality, or physical or mental circumstances, you can be a Muslim. Or a Christian. Or an atheist. Beliefs are at the core of what makes us who we are.

Comment: *NO*, absolutely not!  That is a completely ridiculous proposal that should be squashed with prejudice.

Not only would it raise cost on consumers, it is completely misguided from a moral perspective.  It is a tax based on the assumption that somehow people should be force to pay for content they don't want.

The best Canadian media industries are using the internet as an opportunity and are thriving.  The Internet has opened up new markets and opportunities for content providers unlike anything we've seen in decades, perhaps forever.  These best and brightest would be punished by such a tax.

By contrast the companies and individuals producing sub-par content that no one wants are the ones that are suffering and who would benefit from this tax.

Such a tax is meant to punish success and reward failure.  It hurts consumers in the short term and reduces the quality of Canadian content in the long term.

The Allies, especially the British, had no compunction whatsoever about bombing German cities. Comment: " what constitutes sexual assault"
I would go even further. When someone hears "sexual assault" they think "rape" but in fact sexual assault covers a very wide range of behaviours. The inclusion of things like an unwanted kiss into the same overarching category of sexual assault that includes rape may make it seem like there is an epidemic of rape. 
A million dollar bank robbery and a $10 shoplift are both theft but if all we talked about was the total number of thefts it could seem like there is an epidemic of bank robberies happening on every street corner. That why have theft over $5,000 and theft under $5,000, and people use those terms to ensure a clear picture is being given.
If we wanted clear, useful and informed discussion on the issues by the public we would have very different names for each class of sexual assault, just like we have "theft" and "theft under $5,000",  and writers would use those category names when writing. And clarity is what we all want, right?

Comment: Bryan, I've killed dozens of bears and captured and handled more than that. Never saw hate in a bear's eyes. I've seen curiosity, wariness, fear and desperation. Never hate.

Despite your protestations, as recently as 2014 Fish and Game has admitted that sport hunting and hunter-based control efforts, including bear baiting and even bear snaring, does not reduce black bear populations. The only effective way to reduce a population, so far, has been state employees shooting the bears from helicopters. Even then a black bear population will recover in a few years. http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=pressreleases.pr05292014

If you have any more recent proof - not hypothetical or otherwise specious claims - of bear baiters reducing bear populations, please post them.

Comment: http://fortune.com/2016/03/02/donald-trump-tax-returns-income/
Why Donald Trump's Tax Returns May Prove He's Not That Rich
A balance sheet released in June, when Trump declared his candidacy for President, and a 92-page Personal Financial Disclosure (PFD) form submitted to the Federal Election Commission a month later.
Neither document is as telling as a tax return would be. But when closely read together, you can learn a great deal about Trump’s financial affairs.
Trump appears to have overstated his income, by a lot, which could be the reason he has so far tried to avoid releasing his returns.
By adding up all the revenue that Trump claims as income, a clearer picture emerges of the GOP frontrunner’s business interests. His enterprise looks a heck of a lot smaller than the real estate colossus the candidate claims
Trump may be paying a relatively small amount to Uncle Sam simply because his business isn’t huge.

He is hiding something.

Comment: If you know anything about foreign justice systems, you'll know life isn't very good in the prisons of Albania, Guatemala, Cuba, Liberia, Philippines and India. Torture is common, if not routine. As is denial of legal rights. Currently, in the Philippines, the police aren't even arresting many accused. The president, Rodrigo Duterte, has authorized them to execute suspects on the spot. Thousands have been murdered by the police. And yet- you may have guessed it- Canada has extradition treaties with all those countries.

There are two good reasons for Canada to have an extradition treaty with China. First, Canada is currently a safe haven for many Chinese criminals. Second, if we wish to see China's justice system improve, it will happen quicker if we influence it through interaction. There is mutual benefit to be had in an extradition treaty with China. Stop being hypocritical, put in the proper safeguards, and write the thing.

Comment: It's been 8 years since Billy left. What a respected drummer, even though he played backwards. Besides the R n R bands, he backed The Ink Spots, The 4 Aces & even Jimmy Soul (If you wanna be happy for the rest of your life. . .). No one was funnier. All of us wanted to be the butt of one of Billy's jokes. I was his doctor and once he showed up in my packed waiting room with no appt. My secretary, after checking our charts, said, "Mr. Hilton you haven't been here for some time. Why?" "I've been sick", he replied. The waiting room howled and insisted he be seen first.
Billy was good-looking and women chased him. I asked him what it was like with girls on the road. "It was scary. They would scream and pound and scratch at my hotel room door and at about 3 a.m. I'd let them out". That all ended when he met Stephanie. 
He faced his final diagnosis with a grin and a knowing twinkle in his eye. With tongue in cheek he sang My Way to BW. He died 2 days later. There was a bar at his funeral. A1
